greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = number of powerful divisors d (excluding 1) of n.
comment: a(n) = number of divisors d of n from set A001694(m) - powerful numbers for m >=2.
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
D. Suryanarayana and R. Sitaramachandra Rao, The number of square-full divisors of an integer, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 34 (1972), 79-80
formula: a(1) = 0, a(p) = 0, a(pq) = 0, a(pq...z) = 0, a(p^k) = k-1, for p, q = primes, k = natural numbers, pq...z = product of k (k > 2) distinct primes p, q, ..., z.
example: For n = 12, set of such divisors is {4}; a(12) = 1.
maple: f:=  n -> convert(map(t->t[2], ifactors(n)[2]),`*`) - 1; # _Robert Israel_, Jul 14 2014
mathematica: powerfulQ[n_] := Min[ Last@# & /@ FactorInteger[n]] > 1; f[n_] := Length@ Select[ Divisors@ n, powerfulQ]; Array[f, 105] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 14 2014 *)
results.author: _Jaroslav Krizek_, Dec 25 2010
